content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It adds a good puzzle on two-dimensional traversal to CodinGame members.
An interesting problem.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle with multiple possible approaches. (E.g. mine is slightly different from the example solution.) 
I see the comments about statement ambiguity were dealt with, in the current form I find the statement clear.
very fun problem to solve with the right difficulty!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproving

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Tbh pretty interesting puzzle

Love the puzzle idea but it took me a second to figure it out (I thought test 2 was a triangle . . .) and I probably couldn't have without the test cases. Could you specify that the polygon is all right angles and horizontal/vertical lines (aka rectilinear)?
Pretty cool puzzle! Not sure the dots around are necessary but it doesn't impact.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Appropriate level of difficulty. More interesting than simply counting the number of adjacent squares. Pleasant puzzle to do

❌ Rejected the contribution.
The difficulty level of this exercise should be 'easy' rather than 'medium', as it is too simple and doesn't provide much of a challenge. It would be better suited in the 'Clash of Code' category.

To make it more interesting, a suggestion would be to add additional dimensions, for example in 3D.

One idea: an angle with the character '!' could be worth twice as much, adding an extra layer of complexity and making the exercise more engaging.

Test 4 and validator 4 are trivial. Is it a good idea to move them at the beginning?

After reading the entity statement, I thought we had to find the shape's sides, including oblique lines. "How many sides does it have?" can be reformulated to "How many vertical and horizontal sides does a black-pixeled-right-angular shape have?" or something similar that expresses the orientations of lines.

I like this graphics/geometry puzzle. 
It tickles a nostalgic Convex Hull soft spot for me.
Kudos!
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Well, I got all tests passed, so it's just enough understandable
the input could be 0 and 1 btw
IMHO, you could add an optional "starting point" to force detection at this position
The goal might be to get a robust algorithm for shape detection to isolate a pattern within an image (by levering pixels for exemple, witch would lead to potentially many areas, user could use the mouse to select the shape to detect ... like magic wand in photoshop)

Nice challenge actually

I really like this problem, but I just have a few suggestions. 

1) When you mention the hole, a hole could also be a group of white pixels all surrounded by black pixels, right? Maybe extend the definition to include this.

2) For Test 5 and Validator 5, maybe make them both horizontal or vertical (and could add another testcase if you want to check both) as the user may have coded the horizontal and vertical sides separately and it would be useful to get feedback on both.

Apart from that, I like how closely the testcases are linked and everything else!

Thanks for the feedback!
1. You're totally right, I've changed "white pixel" -> "group of white pixels".
2. I've separated length-1 and width-1 rectangles into two different test cases.
Thanks, glad you liked it. Though I don't know what you mean by starting point.
Glad you liked it :)

Hello,
Test/validator 4 are meant to cover an edge case. I think it’s ok to show the 2x2 square at the beginning.  

Since the polygon is made of “pixels”/squares it should be clear what the polygon looks like.
I think your proposed formulation is much harder to understand.

It's one of the constraints:
- The black pixels form a single connected region.

Hmmm… difficulty level can be highly subjective. I myself feel that it's appropriate to classify this contribution as a Medium puzzle. Easy might be ok too. But it might be too hard as a clash of code considering the time limit.
Glad you liked it! Some solutions (including mine) use the outer dots.
Hi, the statement begins with “You have an NxN grid consisting of white and black square pixels”.
I think it's reasonable, as our screen are also grids and we don't care the shape of the pixels, triangles can still be formed with pixel of any shape
I added an extra paragraph at the end. (Even though I think it is just repeating the above paragraphs..)
Thank you!
I totally agree with 5DN1L

This is definitely unsuitable for clash of code. It is not as trivial as you think. 

As for your suggestions, 
- 3D would make the puzzle completely different and probably extremely difficult 
- adding "!" does not make sense to me (it's unclear what you mean by worth twice as much), also I think adding random complications does not necessarily make a puzzle more engaging
For what it's worth, I agree that it's easy but too much work for a clash.

Initially, I thought this constraint was justified, but after repeating the exercise several times, I couldn't really see its relevance. It seems this constraint is only useful for limiting tests, but not the code itself. I find this disappointing because a pattern like:
..........
.########.
.#...............#.
.#. #### . #.
.#. #..  #.   #.
.#. #..  #.   #.
.#. ####.  #.
.#.............. #.
.########.
.....................
This keeps the tone while emphasizing your suggestion for improvement!

The whole point of the puzzle is to find the number of sides of a region. Normally when talking about “number of sides” you are referring to a single shape, and this puzzle reflects that.

Regions with holes such as your example are problematic because then the meaning of “number of sides” will become ambiguous.

I understand what you mean by 'perimeter,' usually referring to a single, simple shape. But personally, I prefer a fun exercise rather than getting caught up in those complex issues. I don’t think it’s a real difficulty. 
As mentioned above, it won’t change the solution or the level of difficulty, but seeing your code tackle something more complex than what you initially thought is really rewarding and exciting.
Who knows, it might even inspire future careers in mathematics—Fractal Geometry, anyone?!

Everyone knows what "number of sides" is in normal polygons so I don't need to explain it. But with holes it's not so obvious. How would you explain it? I think it will just lead to more text and more people getting confused.
I thought the puzzle was nice because it is intuitively clear what the problem is asking for.

Disconnected polygons breaks the solution, which uses the fact "number of corners = number of sides". If you solved it, what happens with this test case?

4
....
.#..
..#.
....
I added dots instead of spaces, but yes, that's not the case we're dealing with.
I cannot use your suggestion because then solutions no longer work, such the testcase that I posted.
I am not sure if the title is well chosen. When I read "Pixel Polygons" for the first time, I thought it was about polygons that can be reduced to a pixel. What about "Pixeled Polygons"?
